dt: {bc}an explosive device fused to detonate under specified conditions

{bc}a pressure vessel for conducting chemical experiments
{bc}a container for an aerosol (such as an insecticide) {bc}{sx|spray can||}
{bc}a rounded mass of lava exploded from a volcano

et: borrowed from Spanish or Italian {it}bomba{/it} or French {it}bombe,{/it} all probably in part from an onomatopoeic base {it}bomb-{/it} (as in Greek {it}bómbos{/it} "booming, humming," Old Norse {it}bumba{/it} "drum," Lithuanian {it}bambėti{/it} "to mutter, mumble," Albanian {it}bumbullin{/it} "it is thundering"), in part back-formation from Medieval Latin {it}bombardus{/it} or Middle French {it}bombarde{/it} {et_link|bombard:1|bombard:1}

The origin and transmission of {it}bomba, bombe,{/it} etc., in the sense "explosive device, projectile, etc.," among European languages is not certain. {it}Bomba{/it} is attested earliest in Spanish, appearing several times in the second half of the 16th century (canto 18 of {it}La Araucana{/it} of Alonso de Ercilla y Zúñiga, the {it}Descripción general de África{/it} of Luis del Mármol, the {it}Historia de las cosas … del Gran Reyno de la China{/it} of Juan González de Mendoza). Mendoza's book (1585) is the source of an early and aberrant instance of {it}bomb{/it} in English: his {it}bombas de fuego{/it} is rendered as "bomes of fire" in Robert Parke's translation ({it}The Historie of the Great and Mightie Kingdome of China,{/it} London, 1588, p. 65). {it}Bomba{/it} is recorded as Italian in Antoine Oudin's Italian-French dictionary ({it}Recherches italiennes et françoises,{/it} Paris, 1640), where it is glossed "bombe, ou balon de feu" ("bomb, or ball of fire"), though it is not recorded in an Italian text until 1686 (Paolo Segneri, {it}Il cristiano instruito,{/it} Florence, p. 327); Oudin's gloss also apparently constitutes the first record in French. Significantly earlier than any of these is Latin {it}bombus,{/it} which occurs twice in the {it}Commentarii,{/it} an account of the exploits of the condottiere Jacopo Piccinino in 1452-53 by the Neapolitan humanist Giannantonio de' Pandone, "il Porcellio" (ca. 1405-85); Pandone's {it}bombus{/it} appears to be some sort of exploding projectile ("Hic Tibertus Dux bombi fulmine in ulna sauciatur" - "Here Tibertus [the condottiere Tiberto Brandolini] was wounded in the forearm by the flash of a bombus"); the 18th-century lexicographer Du Cange, in {it}Glossarium mediae et infimae Latinitatis,{/it} glosses {it}bombus{/it} in this passage, alluding to French {it}bombe,{/it} as {it}pila incendiaria,{/it} "fireball." Spanish {it}bomba{/it} in the sense "pump," attested from the early 16th century, is probably an independent formation; cf. {et_link|pump:1|pump:1}.
shortdef: an explosive device fused to detonate under specified conditions
atomic bomb; also : nuclear weapons in general —usually used with the
a vessel for compressed gases: such as

dt: {bc}to attack with or as if with {a_link|bombs} {bc}{sx|bombard||}

dt.t: Allen tried a new slider pitch without success and was {wi}bombed{/wi} in Cincinnati.

dt: {bc}to hit (a ball, puck, or shot) very hard

dt.t: {wi}bomb{/wi} a long drive down the fairway
The movie {wi}bombed{/wi} at the box office.

utxt.t: The city was subjected to heavy {wi}bombing{/wi} during the war.

shortdef: to attack with or as if with bombs : bombard
to score many runs against (a pitcher)

dt: {bc}a powerful, rapidly intensifying storm associated with a sudden and significant drop in atmospheric pressure

dt.t: Tens of thousands of utility workers were working over the weekend after the muscular storm—known as a "{wi}bomb cyclone{/wi}" for its rapid pressure drop—battered neighborhoods from Virginia to Maine.

As incoming air rises around the center of the storm, it gets carried off by the jet stream and that increases the speed of the incoming air. The faster the air moves, the faster the barometric pressure drops. In a really severe nor'easter, the pressure can drop 24 millibars in 24 hours. This is known as a "{wi}bomb cyclone{/wi}."

shortdef: a powerful, rapidly intensifying storm associated with a sudden and significant drop in atmospheric pressure

dt: {bc}a situation in which people are afraid because someone says that a bomb is going to explode

dt: {bc}a message saying that a bomb is located in a particular place

dt.t: Someone called in a {it}bomb threat{/it}, so the building was evacuated.

shortdef: a message saying that a bomb is located in a particular place

dt: {bc}a bomb whose violent explosive power is due to the sudden release of energy resulting from the splitting of nuclei of a heavy chemical element (such as plutonium or uranium) by neutrons in a very rapid chain reaction
{bc}a nuclear weapon (such as a hydrogen bomb)

shortdef: a bomb whose violent explosive power is due to the sudden release of energy resulting from the splitting of nuclei of a heavy chemical element (such as plutonium or uranium) by neutrons in a very rapid chain reaction —called also atom bomb
a nuclear weapon (such as a hydrogen bomb)

dt: {bc}an unguided jet-propelled missile used by the Germans against England in World War II
